context: Act 3 Chapter 3.3 — Law enforcement closes in. Escape or face arrest. Chase sequence.

lines.text: 4:15 AM. A knock on the hotel door. Not a polite knock — the kind that announces itself with the authority of a warrant.
You're already awake. You haven't slept properly in days. Through the peephole: uniforms. Badges. The business end of a legal system that has decided you are a problem.

lines.speaker: Police Officer
lines.text: Open the door. We have a warrant for your arrest.
The window. Fifth floor. Fire escape. It's not a plan — it's a reflex. The underground taught you many things, and one of them is that running is always an option until it isn't.

choices.text: Go out the fire escape. Run.

lines.label: fire_escape
lines.text: The fire escape shakes under your weight. Five stories of rusted metal and bad decisions. You hit the alley at a sprint.
Your car — the only one left, a beater CRX that Maya kept running out of loyalty — is parked two blocks away. You reach it as the first sirens start.
The engine starts. It sounds different now — not the CRX of your championship days. This engine coughs and wheezes and takes a full second to find its rhythm. But it runs.

Downtown Nova Pacifica. 4:30 AM. The streets are empty except for you and the growing chorus of sirens. You drive the way you drove in the beginning — by feel, by instinct, by the desperate mathematics of a person with nowhere to go.
Alley. Left turn. Through the market district. Under the overpass. Past Maya's garage — dark, closed, a monument to a life that used to make sense.
The sirens fall behind. The city swallows you. You drive until the road runs out at the harbor, where the container ships wait in darkness like sleeping giants.
Handcuffs. Rights read. The walk through the hotel lobby under the fluorescent gaze of night staff who will sell this story to every outlet that calls.
The back of a police car. The seat is hard and the cage is cold and the sirens are off because you came quietly. Through the window, Nova Pacifica slides past — the city that made you, unmaking you.
Processing. Fingerprints. Photographs. A cell that smells like bleach and despair. Hours that feel like years.
And then — released. Bail posted. The charges are thin and someone — Jade, probably — made sure the right lawyer showed up at the right time.

lines.label: raid_aftermath
lines.text: Dawn. Nova Pacifica wakes up and goes to work and doesn't care that your world just ended. The city does what cities do — it absorbs individual catastrophes into the general noise of being alive.
You are free, technically. But freedom with nowhere to go is just another kind of prison.
The championship trophy is in a storage unit. The corporate apartment has been reclaimed. The underground circuits are too dangerous with your face on every screen.
What's left is a car that barely runs and a city that used to be yours and a silence that is louder than any engine you've ever heard.
